title: Robot Components ü§ñ
ques: What are the essential **components** of a robotic system?

answer.content:
**Robot System Components:**

| Component | Function | Example |
|-----------|----------|--------|
| **Manipulator** | Physical structure, links & joints | Robot arm |
| **End Effector** | Tool at end | Gripper, welding torch |
| **Actuators** | Create motion | Electric motors, hydraulics |
| **Sensors** | Gather environment info | Cameras, encoders |
| **Controller** | "Brain" - processes & commands | Microcontroller, PC |
| **Power Supply** | Energy source | Battery, mains |

explanation: Degrees of freedom (DOF) = number of independent motions. Industrial arms typically have 6 DOF.

title: Types of Robots ü¶æ
ques: Compare different **robot configurations**: Cartesian, SCARA, and Articulated.

answer.content:
| Configuration | Joints | Workspace | Use |
|---------------|--------|-----------|-----|
| **Cartesian** | 3 linear (XYZ) | Box | 3D printing, pick-place |
| **SCARA** | 2 rotary + 1 linear | Cylindrical | Assembly, packaging |
| **Articulated** | All rotary | Complex sphere | Welding, painting |

**Others:**
- Cylindrical (1 linear + 2 rotary)
- Spherical/Polar
- Delta (parallel links)

explanation: Configuration choice depends on payload, reach, speed, precision, and application requirements.

title: Kinematics üìê

answer.content:
**Forward Kinematics:**
Given: Joint angles ‚Üí Find: End effector position

**Inverse Kinematics:**
Given: Desired position ‚Üí Find: Joint angles

**Example (2-link arm):**
- Forward: Œ∏‚ÇÅ, Œ∏‚ÇÇ ‚Üí (x, y)
- Inverse: (x, y) ‚Üí Œ∏‚ÇÅ, Œ∏‚ÇÇ

**Challenges with Inverse:**
- Multiple solutions possible
- No solution (out of reach)
- Singular configurations
- Computationally complex

explanation: Denavit-Hartenberg parameters provide systematic forward kinematics. Inverse often solved numerically.

title: Sensors for Robots üì°

answer.content:
**Proprioceptive (Internal State):**
| Sensor | Measures |
|--------|----------|
| Encoder | Joint position |
| Tachometer | Motor speed |
| Strain gauge | Force/torque |
| IMU | Orientation, acceleration |

**Exteroceptive (External Environment):**
| Sensor | Measures |
|--------|----------|
| Camera | Vision |
| LiDAR | 3D point cloud |
| Ultrasonic | Distance |
| Touch/pressure | Contact |

explanation: Sensor fusion combines multiple sensors for robust perception. Cameras + LiDAR common for autonomous vehicles.

title: Motion Planning üó∫Ô∏è
ques: What is **path planning** and what algorithms are used?

answer.content:
**Path Planning:**
Find collision-free path from start to goal

**Common Algorithms:**
| Algorithm | Type | Pros |
|-----------|------|------|
| **A*** | Graph search | Optimal, complete |
| **RRT** | Sampling-based | Fast in high DOF |
| **PRM** | Sampling-based | Multi-query |
| **Potential Fields** | Gradient descent | Simple, real-time |

**Motion Planning adds:**
- Dynamics constraints
- Velocity/acceleration limits
- Trajectory smoothing

explanation: High-dimensional planning (e.g., 6-DOF arm) is challenging. RRT and PRM are probabilistically complete.

title: Control Systems üéÆ
ques: How is **PID control** applied in robotics?

answer.content:
**PID Controller:**
$$u(t) = K_p e(t) + K_i \int e(t)dt + K_d \frac{de(t)}{dt}$$

| Term | Effect | Fixes |
|------|--------|-------|
| **Proportional** | Immediate response | Reduces error |
| **Integral** | Eliminates steady-state | Offset |
| **Derivative** | Dampens oscillation | Overshoot |

**In Robotics:**
- Each joint may have its own PID
- Gains tuned for response
- Model-based control more accurate

explanation: Ziegler-Nichols method for tuning. Advanced: computed torque, impedance control.

title: Computer Vision üëÅÔ∏è
ques: How do robots use **computer vision** for perception?

answer.content:
**Vision Tasks:**
| Task | Application |
|------|------------|
| Object detection | Identify items to pick |
| Pose estimation | Orient gripper correctly |
| Visual SLAM | Build map, locate self |
| Semantic segmentation | Understand scene |

**Common Approaches:**
- Classical: Edge detection, feature matching
- Deep learning: CNNs, YOLO, Mask R-CNN
- 3D: Depth cameras, stereo vision

**Calibration:** Camera intrinsic/extrinsic parameters

explanation: Hand-eye calibration relates camera to robot frame. Real-time processing requires efficient algorithms or GPUs.

title: Human-Robot Interaction ü§ù
ques: What safety considerations exist for **collaborative robots (cobots)**?

answer.content:
**Collaborative Robot Safety:**

**ISO 10218, ISO/TS 15066 Standards:**

| Method | Description |
|--------|------------|
| Safety-rated stop | Stop when human enters zone |
| Hand guiding | Human physically guides robot |
| Speed & separation | Slow down near humans |
| Force limiting | Reduce force on contact |

**Cobot Features:**
- Rounded edges
- Force/torque sensors
- Lightweight construction
- No pinch points

explanation: Cobots work alongside humans without cages. Speed and payload typically lower than industrial robots.

title: Mobile Robots üöó

answer.content:
**SLAM:**
Build map of environment while tracking position within it

**Chicken-and-egg problem:**
- Need map to localize
- Need location to build map

**Components:**
1. State estimation (Kalman filter, particle filter)
2. Landmark detection
3. Data association
4. Map updating

**Types:**
- Visual SLAM (cameras)
- LiDAR SLAM
- Feature-based vs Dense

explanation: SLAM enables autonomous navigation. Self-driving cars, vacuum robots, drones all use SLAM variants.

title: Actuators üí™
ques: Compare **electric, hydraulic, and pneumatic** actuators for robots.

answer.content:
| Type | Pros | Cons | Use |
|------|------|------|-----|
| **Electric** | Precise, clean, quiet | Lower power density | Most robots |
| **Hydraulic** | Very powerful | Heavy, messy, complex | Heavy lifting |
| **Pneumatic** | Fast, compliant | Low precision | Grippers, simple tasks |

**Electric Motors:**
- DC brushed: Simple, cheap
- Brushless DC: Efficient, long life
- Stepper: Open-loop positioning
- Servo: Closed-loop control

explanation: Gearboxes increase torque but reduce speed. Backdrivable systems allow force control.
